results.title: La Guerre des Boutons = War of the Buttons
results.brief_description:
Two rival gangs of small boys wage a daily battle in a sandpit between their two villages, taking prisoners whose belts, braces and buttons are cut off. Lebrac, leader of one gang, conceives the idea of surprising the other side by going into battle naked and chalks up a victory. As the war games become more elaborate, the parents have to intervene. The movie was a huge commercial success on initial release, but it is unlikely to appeal much to those more interested in the infinitely complex and unequivocally nasty ‘The Lord of the Flies’. Awards: Prix Jean Vigo 1962. Reference: Bloomsbury Foreign Film Guide.

Credits: Producers, Yves Robert, Daniele Delorme ; director, Yves Robert ; writers, Yves Robert, Francois Boyer ; photography, Andre Bac ; music, Jose Berghams.
Cast: Andre Teton, Martin Lartigues, Michel Isella, Jacques Dufilho, Jean Richard, Michel Galabru, Paul Crauchet, Pierre Trabaud, Yvette Etievant, Robert Rollis.

results.title: Le Silence Est D'or = Silence Is Golden
results.brief_description:
The first postwar US/France co-production (Pathe/RKO), ‘Le silence est d’or’ is a tribute to the pioneering days of cinema. Emile Clement is a director of silent films in early 20th century Paris. He is also a father figure to his staff, especially to Jacques, his assistant, to whom he is imparting his knowledge about women. When Madeleine, a young actress joins the studio, Emile immediately falls in love with her. By chance, Jacques meets Madeleine on train trip, unaware of her relationship with Emile. He decides to apply the lessons in seduction dispensed by his employer and mentor.

Credits: Producer, E. Lepage ; director, Rene Clair ; writer, Rene Clair ; photography, Armand Thirard ; music, Georges van Parys ; costumes, Christian Dior ; art direction, Leon Barsacq, Guy de Gastyne.
Cast: Maurice Chevalier, Marcelle Derrien, Francois Perier, Dany Robin, Raymond Cordy, Max Dalban, Bruno Balp, Gaston Modot, Armontel.

results.title: Hush-a-bye baby
results.creator_credit: Margo Harkin, Tom Collins, British Screen Finance, Channel 4 and Derry Film and Video Workshop
results.brief_description: Set in the Catholic community in Derry, Ireland, at the time of the ‘supergrass’ trials in the wake of the abortion referendum in the Republic, this is the story of four teenage girls: Goretti (Emer McCourt); Sinead (Sinead O’Connor); Dinky (Cathy Casey) and Majella (Julie Rodgers). In particular it revolves around their attempts to come to grips with their sexuality in a confusing and oppressive culture. Things come to a head when Goretti becomes pregnant by her boyfriend Ciarin (Michael Liebman), who, meanwhile has been lifted in an army swoop. This is a tough yet wholly sympathetic view of a working class community, a view which whilst touchingly communicating the vulnerability of young people exploring their sexuality, never romanticises the attitudes of its characters toward each other.

results.title: Un Taxi Pour Tobruk = Taxi to Tobruk (Cinemascope Print)
results.brief_description:
In this WW II adventure, a band of French soldiers, separated from their unit, must escort a group of high-ranking German officers they have captured across the North African desert. Along the way a strange bond develops between the men, one of whom is Jewish. Just before they reach their destination, they are attacked by their own troops who do not recognize them. The films bears the usual trademarks of Michel Audiard’s rapide fire one liners.

Credits: Director, Denys de la Patelliere ; writers, Rene Havard, Michel Audiard ; photography, Marcel Grignon ; music, Georges Garvarentz.
Cast: Lino Ventura, Charles Aznavour, Maurice Biraud, Hardy Kruger.

results.title: Une Semaine de Vacances = a Week's Vacation
results.brief_description:
A Lyons schoolteacher in her early thirties suffers from severe depression as a result of a crisis of faith in her work and unresolved differences in her relationship whith her lover. On doctor’s orders she take a week off during which she visits her parents and has several encounters, notably with the father of one of her pupils. Placed specifically in time - Winter, 1980 - and place - Lyons, its landscape filmed with loving detail - this is a portrait of a woman trying to find sense and direction in her life.

Credits: Director, Bertrand Tavernier ; writers, Bertrand Tavernier, Marie-Francoise Hans, Colo Tavernier ; photography, Pierre William Glenn ; music, Pierre Papadiamandis.
Cast: Nathalie Baye, Gerard Lanvin, Michel Galabru, Philippe Noiret.

results.title: Un type comme moi ne devrait jamais mourir = A Guy Like Me Should Never Die
results.brief_description:
Leopold is an investment broker who is so opposed to war that he transfers his entire personal portfolio into chocolates, reasoning that this is a product that can never be turned to war-like use. One day, Leopold feels the need to break his old routine and leaves wife and career behind in order to meditate on the meaning of life.

Credits: Producer, Bernard Lenteric ; director, Michel Vianey ; writer, Michel Vianey ; photography, Georges Barsky ; music, Mort Schuman.
Cast: Jean-Michel Folon, Francine Racette, Bernard Fresson, Mort Schuman, Henri Garcin, Pierre Barouh, Bernadette Lafont.

results.title: Cesar
results.brief_description:
After his years in the merchant navy Marius runs a garage in Toulon. On the death of her husband, Panisse, Fanny reveals to her adult son Cesariot that Marius is his father. With a liitle help from grandfather Cesar, the lovers of 20 years before are reunited. This final entry in Pagnol’s Marseilles trilogy (preceded by ‘Marius’ and ‘Fanny’) is the only one of the three directed by Pagnol.

Credits: Producer, Marcel Pagnol ; director, Marcel Pagnol ; writer, Marcel Pagnol ; photography, Willy [Faktorovitch], Roger Ledru ; music, Vincent Scotto.
Cast: Raimu, Pierre Fresnay, Orane Demazis, Ropbert Vattier, Charpin, Maupi.

results.title: Le Doulos = the Finger Man
results.creator_credit: Georges de Beauregard and Jean-Pierre Melville
results.brief_description:
Maurice, just out of jail, seeks out revenge from a fence who had his wife killed. Maurice kills the fence and steels some jewellery which he hides. But the murder is not enough. Maurice prepares an other heist with Silien, whom the ‘milieu’ (the underworld) suspects to be a ‘doulos’ (an informer). ‘Le Doulos’ is one of Melville’s many homages to American Cinema. The sets for the offices of Commissaire Clain were modelled on those used by Ruben Mamoulian in ‘City Streets’. For the confrontation scene between Silien and Clain, Melville directed a 9 min. 39 sec. shot with a 360 degree pan.

Credits: Producer, Georges de Beauregard ; director, Jean-Pierre Melville ; writers, Jean-Pierre Melville, Elisabeth Rappeneau ; photography, Nicolas Hayer ; music, Paul Misraki ; art direction, Daniel Gueret, Pierre Charron ; assistant directior, Vol
Cast: Jean-Paul Belmondo, Serge Reggiani, Jean Desailly, Fabienne Dali, Michel Piccoli, Marcel Cuvelier, Jack Leonard, Aime de March, Monique Hennessy.

results.title: Leon Morin, Pretre = Leon Morin, Priest
results.creator_credit: Carlo Ponti, Georges de Beauregard and Jean-Pierre Melville
results.brief_description:
Aiming successfully for a wider audience in 1961, the neglected French independent Jean-Pierre Melville (‘Les enfants terribles’, ‘Le samourai’) adapted Beatrix Beck’s autobiographical novel, set in a French village during World War II, about a young woman falling in love with a handsome, radical young priest who is fully aware of his power over her. For the starring roles Melville, godfather of the New Wave, ironically selected two talented actors catapulted to fame by that movement— Emmanuelle Riva (‘Hiroshima mon amour’) and Jean-Paul Belmondo (‘Breathless’). The poetic results are literary and personal; the heroine’s offscreen narration suggests the pre-Bressonian form of Melville’s first feature, ‘Le silence de la mer’, and sudden subjective shots convey the woman’s physical proximity to the priest as she undergoes an ambiguous religious conversion. Not an unqualified success, the film remains strong for its performances, its inventive editing and framing, and its evocative rendering of the French Occupation. According to Melville, the film ran for 193 minutes in its pre-release form; he edited out 65 minutes, and another 18 minutes are missing from the present version. The eclectic and resourceful non jazz score is by jazz pianist Martial Solal. Reference: Jonathan Rosenbaum, Chicago Reader. Online. http://onfilm.chireader.com Awards: Grand Prix de la Ville de Venise, 1961.

Credits: Producers, Georges de Beauregard, Carlo Ponti ; director, Jean-Pierre Melville ; writer, Jean-Pierre Melville ; photography, Henri Decae, Jean Rabier ; music, Martial Solal ; assistant director, Volker Schlondorff.
Cast: Jean-Paul Belmondo, Emmanuelle Riva, Howard Vernon.

results.title: The Treasure of Sierra Madre
results.creator_credit: John Huston, Henry Blanke and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: John Huston won Academy Awards both as director and writer of this film. Based on B. Traven’s novel, it reveals the effects of greed and the lure of sudden wealth on three penniless prospectors. Humphrey Bogart, as Fred C. Dobbs, gives one of the best performances of his career. We watch him change from a likeable drifter into a man capable of killing his best friend in cold blood.
